Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Expectation2: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation2: Roads are dry with light traffic and normal speed limits
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, half-listening as my family tossed around ideas for the weekend. My sister wanted to go hiking, my brother suggested a movie, and my mom hoped we’d all have dinner together. They looked at me, expecting me to chime in, to promise I’d be there. As their brother, I knew how much it meant to them that I join in, that I be present and part of these moments. But in the back of my mind, I couldn’t stop thinking about my taxi shifts. Weekends were busy, and I was expected to be on the road, alert and careful, following every traffic law, especially with the light traffic making it easy to speed without noticing. My boss had warned me: one more ticket and I’d be out. I felt the weight of both roles pressing on me—my family’s hope for togetherness, my responsibility to drive safely and keep my job. My heart pounded as I tried to figure out how I could possibly meet both expectations, knowing I’d have to choose.
